AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: Psychonauts Original Release: 2005 Genre Tags: Adventure; RPG; Platformer; Lighthearted; Psychedelic My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamersREVIEWPsychonauts is a quirky and imaginative action-adventure game that is an absolute riot.  It is an aging specimen, but it will forever hold a status as a highly enjoyable “cult classic.”  If it has piqued your interest, then I suggest you take a complimentary cup of Kool-Aid and join the cult… you won’t regret it.Psychonauts excels at many things.  The story, the characters, and the writing are all top-notch and well-executed.  The scenes and developments throughout the campaign are quite amusing and should keep you thoroughly entertained.  The many different characters are all interesting in their own way.  They are all splendidly eccentric and unique, if not also reminiscent of typical Saturday-morning-cartoon archetypes.  And, importantly, the voice acting is mostly decent and sufficiently holds everything else together… although it does falter slightly, on occasion.   Providing setting for the narrative is a very inspired and diverse gameworld that is quite atmospheric.  The graphics used are undeniably dated and are only increasingly falling farther behind the curve; however the developers did an outstanding job of matching the environments and atmosphere to the overall soul of the game.  There is a mixture of lighthearted, noir, cartoonish, and psychedelic ambiances which really diversifies the experience as you play through the campaign.   You may not be awed by the scenery like in modern games, but you can still easily appreciate the effort that was put into the creation of the gameworld.Of course, the intriguing narrative and captivating atmosphere would be for naught if the gameplay wasn’t enjoyable.  Luckily, Psychonauts is quite fun to play.  There is a pleasant mixture of combat situations and puzzle-solving that you would expect from a game like this.  Situations can be approached by experimentation with various abilities and skills, which you unlock as you progress through the campaign.  Also, the various levels will introduce different dynamics to keep you on your toes.  There are also a ton of collectibles and many achievements to keep you busy, if you are into that kind of thing.Psychonauts can easily appeal to a wide and diverse audience.  The tone is fairly childish, but has many adult themes.  It is also a pretty easy/casual experience, so there shouldn’t be any skill issues.  It takes approximately 14 to 22 hours to complete, depending on if you strive for achievements or not.  If you like 3D action-adventure platformers, I would say this is a pretty safe bet for you.  It is also a good bet for anyone who may be interested in “seeing what the fuss is about,” as you will probably find it enjoyable once given a try.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												     Personally this is my favorite Double Fine game. Although it is about nine years old it still holds up as a good game with an interesting art style. Unlike most games built as an atempt at photorealism, the extremely cartoonish graphics and garish colour palette still looks good almost a decade after release. As all games from Tim Schafer the writing is magnificent, the voice acting is well done and the characters always have something important or hilarious to say. The setting of a Summer camp for Psychics not only influences the plot and gameplay but the dialogues actually sound like something children at summer camp would be saying, except that they are about the outlandish topics involved with a world surrounded by psychic weirdness. The gameplay is devided up into two sections, the overworld with some, but not much combat, sidequests, the one shop in the game, and most of the colorful non-essential dialogue, and the insides of the various character's minds. These minds serve as the various levels of the game, each with the same basic controlls but slightly different gameplay. The Meat Circus level is all about fast paced platforming, whilst Lungfishopolis is completely based on the combat system, and the Milkman level(BEST LEVEL EVER) is an old school inventory adventure puzzle mixed with a fever dream X-Files Plot. Throughout the game you gain psy powers that are used in combat and level navigation, some work as a long range attack with the need to collect ammo, and there is a bouncy ball/parachute power that makes platforming much more difficult and interesting.     Now that i have sufficiently gushed about all the things i freaking love about this game it is time to get realistic and talk about the flaws. Most of these flaws have to do with the fact that this was Double Fine's first attempt at an action game. the combat can be a bit annoying with enemy spamming getting overdone at times, that being said most of the basic enemies are too easy to dispatch and clearing the room becomes simply a chore without much actual difficulty. The controlls are somewhat soft and the platforming would be vastly improved by tighter controlls to allow for fine tuned navigation. and if you watch a let's play you can see that the dificulty scale starts off low but when it does ramp up it does so without telling you and later levels,(Milkman,Meat Circus) can become frustrating and take forever to get past, not allways from dificulty of combat or platforming but in the milkman level if you do not know what you are doing it can be almost impossible to figure some of the puzzles out organically.     All that being said these flaws are really not as bad as it sounds. the increased difficulty lends less to frustraton and more to angry inspiration to just beat this next level and prove that you are better than the game. and for the milkman, a quick glance at a gameFAQ can help if you get too badlt stuck, enough people have been frustrated by the level to have wonderfull walkthroughs made to relieve the tension. in the end the story and experience is so good it makes up for any akwardness in gameplay. 8/10, This game is a love it or hate it, and i love it, fantastic but not even close to perfect.

To get this on Steam is a no brainer as it's an incredibly solid experience that should be experienced by anyone who appreciates Adventure and platforming games and timeless classics.  Psychonauts is one of the best games I’ve ever played. In this long post I will describe in detail why that is true. Psychonauts is a 3D platformer game with very peculiar art style, great characters and awesome story line. 1. Story & Characters  (Spoiler Free don’t worry)The main place where almost every action of the game takes place is a summer camp for children with psychic abilities (Something like X-Men). The main character is named Razputin, Raz for short, a young child which goes alone to that summer camp without his father’s permission.There are around 20 kids in the camp and you can interact with every one of them. There are also a couple of adults which are training the young psychics. The main story is very interesting and will hook you in. I don’t want to say anything related to it because I don’t want to spoil something unintentionally All children[i.imgur.com]2. Gameplay & Graphics.The gameplay is very solid; you have a lot of things to do. The game feels very open world to me. It has 6 separated locations plus a couple more which are not placed on the map. The game features very common gameplay mechanics: Double jump (later on you will acquire something with which you will jump even higher), normal punch attack and 3 slots for special attacks. I highly hope you will ignore the graphics, because they are not so good and hope you will give the game a chance.I highly doubt they will remaster it so no need to wait.3.  Level design.This by far is the best aspect of the game. They are so well made, with high attention to details -  almost perfect. I will always remember 2 levels in my mind: Waterloo World and Milkman Conspiracy.  Both are in the later part of the game. The Waterloo World has such awesome ideas and I will try to explain it without any spoilers. In that level your body can exist in 3 states - Large (normal), medium and small. In order to beat the level, you need to switch between the states and interact with stuff whereby you can’t in other states. Milkman Conspiracy is so abstract it makes you question your sanity (Please don’t think it’s too deep). There are very nice gameplay mechanics in this level and you need to get used to it quite fast so you can beat it (A lot of backtracking for achievement hunters). Almost every level introduces its own gameplay mechanic. And that’s why the game is so good. You never feel bored with it.4. Comedy.Comedy plays a big part in the game. Almost every character is funny on its own. You’ll never feel that a joke is forced. Every joke is balanced and put right on spot. There are 2 abilities which I used more often than necessary, just because they made situations way funnier. The first ability is called Bacon - when you use it, a character appears in your mind and tells you his advice on the current situation, points out weak spots for the boss fights and sometimes makes funny jokes. The other is an ability acquired later on the game, which allows you to see yourself through the eyes of others and - oh, boy - I laughed my ♥♥♥ off with that. The developers put a lot of effort into this ability to show different pictures of you for everything that you can view yourself through. I’m sure I did not get all the jokes and I’m sure there are many more. Seen by a thing which loves cake[i.imgur.com]5. Abilities & Ranking system.There are in total 101 PSI cadet ranks. Once you have gathered a PSI Core combined with 9 PSI cards to it, you are granted a cadet rank. You need to buy a lot of PSI Cores from the in-game shop. There is no such thing as a skill tree in this game. The game gives you abilities when you reach certain cadet rank.6. AchievementsThis is for all who are going to attempt to get all achievements:Most achievements are fairly easy and you will find no problem getting them. Many are story related so you can’t miss them. A couple are quite tricky because if you progress too far in a current level you can’t obtain them anymore.  I used a spoiler-free guide to see when I should take a minute and visit a place.There are 3 very hard achievements:  "I LOVE PUNCHING!" I think this achievement takes place in the very first big level and - oh, boy, believe me - it’s very hard. The problem is that it requires skill but the controls are poorly done for PC users. It’s a living nightmare to do it with keyboard and mouse. I’ve read that it’s easier to achieve with controller. I’ve put in a lot of effort to obtain it. (You will need this achievement for “Math is Hard” achievement)Another very hard achievement is called:"Math is Hard". If you are a collectible hunter by nature you will find no problem in getting this achievement. Briefly explained: you need to collect everything before the POINT OF NO RETURN. And yes there is a certain point where you can’t go back. Personally I’m not a big fan of such implementations, because everyone can ♥♥♥♥ up. At least they put a handy “Save” with the same name (POINT OF NO RETURN) and if you think you’ve missed something you can reload that save and complete those things you’ve missed.The last “hard” achievement is actually not hard at all. It requires you to buy an item from the in-game store (it’s not micro-transaction) on Christmas. I know you can change your PC date and get the achievement very easily, but since Christmas is very close I decided to wait.7. CollectiblesThere are 7 types of collectibles: Figments, Vaults, Emotional Baggage, PSI cards(PSI cards+core), Scavenger hunt items, Brains and Cobwebs. In any part of the map, when you open the menu it shows how many collectibles you can find. There are a lot of figments - like 100 per level and sometimes they blend so much with the level itself it is hard to find them. Vaults are really interesting,  they share screenshots of a certain character’s past and it’s made like an old movie - I love those. There are very messed up vaults which really can affect your mood after seeing them. Emotional Baggages are collected in a strange way. Imagine it to be doors -  you need to find the key and the door itself; sometimes you will find the door before the key.  Usually on every part of the map there are a certain number of PSI cards and like 1 PSI Core (with cards). There are 16 scavenger hunt items in total and some are quite hard to find. Once you gather 8, you are granted 4 levels at once. When you find the rest you get another 4 levels.  Cobwebs are tricky because you need a tool from the in-game shop in order to collect them. Usually there are 5-6 per level. Once gathered you can redeem them for PSI cards.Overall they are fun to collect. You need all of collectibles for “Math is Hard” achievement.All collectables[i.imgur.com]8. How I got to know of this game.FunHause YouTube channel is a channel which I watch very often. One of the members of this channel kept talking about this game non-stop and eventually I checked it out. His name is James  Williems9. Psychonauts 2The game raised 3.5 million dollars through crowdfunding from investors and other people. And I’m super-duper hyped for the second game. They even gave James Williams a voice acting role because he did an insane job popularising the game. Video from the developers10. Final verdict and thoughts.On a scale from 0 to 10, I will give  Psychonauts 9/10 without a doubt. It’s one hell of a good game and with this kind of a review I hope it made you check it out yourself. Huge respect to Double Fine for creating such a good game.Awesome credit picture[i.imgur.com]

												My previous review of this game did not do it justice since I felt it deserved better than that - I'd like to elaborate a bit further on why I love this game ever so much as one of the best innovative games/platformers of all time. Growing up with 2D and 3D platformers like Mario, Crash & Spyro I could easily adapt to the platforming of the game. The platforming itself is solid enough but the actual combat in the game, during times like Boss Battles, can be dodgy as heck if you don't have a controller in handy -- Usually because of several different buttons needed to lock-on enemies and attack or alternatively dodge incoming attacks. You have the option of changing the keys to fit a play-style suitable for yourself, but I still find it frustrating at best namely due to the several important commands required. Here's my advice: Play the game with a controller as it'll make gameplay a bit smoother. So, what makes the game exceptional? Well, first of all it's the premise. The setting is a summer school camp for psychics. The game is brought to us by none other than the master of adventure games, Tim Schäfer (Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Day of the Tentacle), whose characteristic sense of humor certainly blooms in Psychonauts. One of the long running concepts of Schäfer's style usually juxtaposes a rather mundane situation in a fantastical setting; Such as what you'd expect if Tim Burton & David Lynch teamed up for an all-wacky-superstar tag team line up movie. Which is just as well because creator Tim Schäfer has now acquired his very own Johnny Depp, in form of Jack Black, although he's absent from this game. But I digress - We play as Raz, who's chosen to flee from the circus as opposed to joining it, because being a Psychonaut is a lot more fulfilling than the circus obviously. As he gets accepted into the fold of Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp he soon finds himself in the middle of a strange conspiracy, where the brains of the camp's inhabitants mysteriously vanish which leads to the game's funniest moments. The caricatures that show up in the game are so incredibly diverse and... weird? They are truly fascinating as you get to DIG your way inside their subconscious minds to discover their true hidden feelings. Essentially, Schäfer came up with the idea of Inception before... well Inception. This is the unique part of the game - The environments, atmosphere and overall feel of the inner & deepest thoughts of the camp and local areas inhabitants's minds.Let me sum up some of the fascinating characters. We have a mad dentist who harvest brains, a talking fish whose thoughts involves a sequence where you become a giant Godzilla monster terrorizing a society of talking fish, a mentally ill security guard who's lost in the mindset of a crazy pyromaniac-milkman, Napoleon Bonaparte and his dimwit descendant, An aspiring musical starlet whose cruel mother's treatment of her and eventual suicide has caused her to develop a case of bipolar disorder, a government agent who disguises himself as a housewife by brandishing a rolling pin while talking disjointedly about pies etc. These are the kind of characters you can expect alongside the campers themselves and the local counselors, whom all are very well rounded and have their own personalities. Usually they are defined by interacting with them around the camp or examining the local signs and written letters, to provide character depth. Lastly, I found myself jamming to the game's cool blues-inspired guitar stringing soundtrack. All in all It's seemingly -- Well done. If you love a good platformer, with some dodgy gameplay at times, while every now and then laughing your ♥♥♥ off and maybe, just maybe, find yourself sympathizing with some of the loonies, as you uncover their hidden feelings. Then look no further than Psychonauts! :)

												So I picked up Psychonauts in 2016 for $1. People spoke pretty highly of this game, and I wanted something that could run on my laptop, so I got it. It took me about 20 hours to beat (longer than expected) and now that I have, I must say this game is absolutely brilliant. It's not perfect, it can be frustrating and the design isn't as polished as it could be, but I soon reached a point where I was so invested in the characters and storyline I was willing to put up with these blemishes in order to see things through.I'd like to start with the biggest strength of the game: the levels. In the game, you have to stop this sinister plot of lobotomies and kidnappings, and you do so by traveling into the minds of various people, often as a means of getting them to aid you. As such, most of the levels consist of navigating a specific mind, and each mind/level has its own unique aesthetics, mechanics, and tasks to complete. For instance, there's a level in here where you explore a mind that takes the form of a sprawling metropolis, and you play as a Godzilla-like monster that destroys it. The goal of this level is to destroy a tower in the center of the city, there are tanks and other anti-Godzilla weapons, and you get introduced to a shield, which you pretty much have learn to use to beat this level. There's another level where you encounter a mind that places you as a piece in board game. You have to talk to the other pieces (they have fun things to say), and deliver them food or money or munitions in order to deploy them and beat your opponent. This level involves some tricky platforming and light puzzle-solving, and I personally loved its aesthetic. A lot of these levels also feature their own boss/bosses, each of which is as unique as the environment they inhabit, and you'll have to figure out their vulnerabilities and how to exploit them.Since the levels are based on the minds of people you meet, you will encounter all sorts of interesting, complex people. I developed an emotional attachment to many of them which really gave me a sense of satisfaction in beating the various levels. For instance, you meet someone in anguish over a lost love, and it was so cathartic helping that character let go. And many of these characters are not all they seem. You may also punch, levitate, and attempt to ignite many of these characters to hear them make all sorts of indignant responses.I want to touch more on the gameplay. It's a third-person platformer from the PS2 era. Seems pretty bland, but they give you a whole slew of psychic powers and a diverse selection of enemies to use them on. I very much enjoyed the combat, though I wasn't much of a fan of the platforming. (This is partly because I'm not very good at platformers and because I played the whole game with a mouse an keyboard.) There were parts of the game where I'd jump, miss, and then get bumped back to the last checkpoint and have to do it over again. That being said, I feel like the game has enough checkpoint to not be too maddening or punishing. The game really gets difficult towards the end, make no mistake of that, but it's doable if you have the patience.Speaking of frustration, the game does have some annoying design issues. Remember, this is an old game. Because it's third person, sometimes the camera decides to jump behind a wall and you lose sight of your character. The game also gives you a lock-on tool to assist in aiming, and sometimes it doesn't recognize a target and points you in the opposite direction you wanted, and that causes you to miss your window of attack. And there are some glitches like where your character gets stuck, but you can normally jump around to free yourself. Again, if you have the patience, these aren't too damning.In conclusion, the game is clever in its world-building, characters, and gameplay, just remember that it's an old, tough platformer.

												First off I'm gonna tell you one thing, buy this game, and then I'll explain why you should. This game is absolutely fantastic. It's fun, it's got a great story, great characters, and hilarious (if not somewhat cheesy) dialogue.The story is quite interesting, but it's actually really enhanced by the characters. Double Fine did an excellent job of giving every single character (yes even the minor ones) a sense of actual human personality. A 10 year old boy who's running away from the circus to become a psychic agent, a sarcastic girl with the ability to talk to plants and takes no BS from anyone, a timid, socially awkward boy who was told to go to the camp because he kept blowing up people's heads with his mind, and a plethora more of quirky characters really make the game world and gameplay twice as fun and hilarious.However, another thing that Double Fine did that really gave the game some depth is the subtly. If you pay close attention to each character and their dialogue, memory vaults, and figments, you can find out some surprisingly....dark things about them. Even the main character, Razputin, mentions some pretty awful things that happened to him and his family as a child. But these little things add even more character to them, it makes them feel like they could be actual people because who hasn't had bad experiences or trauma in their lives? For a lot of the young campers, how they hint at these really tragic events is very child-like of them, like how an actual kid who can't quite comprehend those kinds of things would describe or talk about them.(You can see that I love the characters in this game right?)Moving on, the combat system is a boatload of fun, with cool abilities that are decently balanced with the gameplay. You can levitate and shoot psychic blasts of energy at your enemies, light almost every living thing on fire, and a bunch more cool things that are required to progress through different levels of the game. Speaking of the game levels, they're coloful and vary from each person's mind you enter, with different bosses and NPCs as well as the variety of different objects and missions that really tell you about the personality of the person's mentality.However, there does tend to be a bit of vagueness in certain levels where I'd get stuck because there was no clear objective or direction to what I was trying to do. At times it was more frustrating than other levels and if you've ever heard of the infamous last level of this game, the difficulty curve just spikes suddenly with how ridiculously hard and unforgiving it can be (and this version on Steam is the easier version of it!). But nonetheless, it kept me playing the game in a raging "I'm going to beat this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level so help me" kind of way.I will say if you're a person who goes for 100% completion or achievements, good luck to you. There's hundreds of these things in the game called figments (like figments of one's imagination) and in some levels they're placed in ridiculously hard to find places. I'm not a person who really cares for those things as much so it never bothered me, but I can definately see how it would irritate some people who either really hate collecting.But aside from those little nitpicks and some level frustrations, I absolutely adore this game (and am currently restarting it) and would reccommend it to as many people as possible so Double Fine can come out with a sequel for it already!

Short version: 88%The cute (but dated) puzzle platformer surface of Psychonauts hides a game teeming with ideas, imagination, and great design choices (plus a not too great control scheme). A game that is worthy of all the praises it got in the past years.Long version:When Tim Schafer started his own company, Double Fine, in 2001, he was mostly known as the somewhat eccentric designer behind the greatest LucasArts adventures. So when their first title, Psychonauts, was finally released in 2005, it was a surprise to see it commercially fail despite the great reviews.Although the game eventually gained the following it deserves, it is easy to understand the initial troubles: on the surface, it looks like a typical early 2000s 3D puzzle platformer with 90s kids’ movie stereotype characters drawn as Nickelodeon figures. It took years to finally understand that its greatness lies under the hood.For starters, there is the plot. Initially, it seems like a summer camp movie about kids who have psychic powers, but as the story goes on, we learn that this movie was apparently directed by Tim Burton, as it slowly turns into a (kid-friendly) nightmare world for our brave protagonist, the somewhat clichéd sassy tough kid Rasputin.This change in atmosphere is anything but subtle, as the game world moves from a somewhat serene campground to a creepy island asylum. Both of these serve mostly as an overworld that ties together the actual levels, all set in the mindscape, the psyche of certain characters.These levels are the main reason behind the late-coming success of Psychonauts. Each offers something brand new game mechanic, ranging from simple platforming to almost point ‘n’ click levels of story-driven puzzle solving. They delve deep in the minds of a character, utilising this to its full extent to tell us an interesting, often bittersweet tale, showing us the full capabilities of the storywriting strength Double Fine could deliver.

												Many people describe this game as a "cult classic", but that does a disservice to a broadly appealing game that does so much right. Psychonauts, nearly a dozen years after release, remains an engaging and entertaining action-adventure 3d platformer that remains one of the funniest video games available. The graphics, while far from impressive by today's standards, have aged well because they focus on expressiveness rather than realism. The platforming, likewise, while plagued by occasional camera-angle issues, is perfectly decent.But the reasons you should play this game are the laughs and the level design. The theme of a psychic who leaps into the minds of others for each level is quite inventive, and unlike most games with inventive themes, this one backs it up with inventive gameplay. From the clean and tidy cube in the mind of the secret agent, to the twisted logic-and-gravity-defying mind of the schizophrenic, to many other hilarious worlds I hesitate to spoil but which introduce new mechanics, each level in Psychonauts feels like its own little masterwork. These are not just the same levels with new skins, or new enemies, each level in this game FEELS very different, and over a decade later I've yet to see a game with better level design.This is one of the true classics -- not just cult classics -- of PC gaming, and anyone who hasn't played it should certainly consider grabbing it during one of those times when it's on sale for a buck, such as today.

												Psychonauts has some outdated game design decisions (we are all immensely bored of collect-all-the-things), but this does not take away from the sheer depth and beauty of it as a platformer and a universe.The game Psychonauts has an intense dedication in immersing you in summer camp for psychics universe. You feel like the other children have their own quests and goals and you see them taking classes with you. It's little details like this that make Psychonauts stand out from other platformers that put all their focus in level design, and the bare minimum in immersion. On top of that, I am very impressed at the overarching theme of exploring the "typical mind fallacy" and in how we tend to overlook the experience and stories of children and those of different cognitive experiences. Early in the game, a child will tell a story that both the player and the teachers conclude is "just a story". Later in the game this "just a story" becomes a clear story point. And Raz is a delightful protagonist. I've never seen a game explore anxiety in its general and social forms so effectively. (I related a bit too strongly to the under-water level.)Despite various outdated game design mechanics, Psychonauts is a classic which should be played by all future game designers if only to learn how important a dedication to world immersion is and how much more satisfying a game mechanic is when it's intimately linked to story and theme.

												I had this in my library for over a year and a half before I finally finished it. I regret to not have done so much earlier, because this is truely an outstanding game. I'm really envious of the amount of creativity. There are so many details and humorous easter eggs. It's pretty lengthy as well. Much content. Lots of good!What makes this game special first and foremost is the jarring design - that makes the characters, the voices, the dialogue, the level architecture + gimmicks and naturally the humour. What I like about it is, that it takes itself serious enough to not become a total joke. It's not constantly funny and that's a good thing.I also like the structure and all the little conveniences. You have a Hub-world with multiple screens where you can free-roam to collect goodies. You have a transit system for fast travel and can get information at every moment so you never have to leave the game if you're stuck. The actual levels are in people's mind, and boy, did they make sure everyone feels unique. They are thinking out of the box more that in the box if you know what I mean. There is also a level select screen, the collective unconscious - another means to give you quick and easy control over where to go.Psychonauts is a blend of different genres. It's a 3D-Platformer but also an Action-Adventure game. These elements are served in rotation and there are long stretches where one of these takes a backseat. For example, sometimes you are significantly jumping around more and collecting stuff, Other times it's more about item management and problem solving and then there is straight-out combat. Very good pacing, both gameplay-wise and visually.And there is a lot to do... the feature list of the game mechanics are staggering. It could be tedious at some point or the other to collect all figments, say like 243 in a huge screen, but most of the time it feels very good to get everything. In some places it is a little glitchy and frustrating. You eventually get annoyed in your attempt to conquer all of it. Like, when you set the enemy on fire and he runs into you and passes in on, making you run around uncontrollably. Or when you can't get enough momentum to jump high enough off off a trampoline. Or when you're trapped in a tight space and jiggle around to get free. Yeah... be prepared for this. At that point you're probably willing to forgive more easily when the game has won you over.A little tip to prevent you from having the same start as me: As soon as you reach level 3 (from 10) you get a new mode of transport and that changes everything.Play with a gamepad!

												First time review, so here it goes:This is a great game. No caveats or buts; it is, without question, a masterpiece.The games is about a young boy named Raz, who ran away from the circus to a summer camp to become a Psychonaut.Once there he meets many quirky and colorful characters and enters their minds to fight their inner-demons, unpack their emotional baggage, and maybe learn to set things on fire.The main strength of this title comes from its focused design. All the pieces just fit well together. The level of minds you must face, the leveling system, the odd off the wall plot, the aft for mentioned cast of characters, the music choices, and the overall sense of the game. A mix of the seemingly familiar wrapped in the trapping of the strange.Some very minor nitpicks I feel I need to add. They are by no means game breakers. In fact I encourage you to go play this game before reading this list. The game doesn't tell you can interact with as many things as you actually can. For my second play through I was using the action button on everything and finding that there's always some throwaway line or gag for nearly every object or person. The figments (one of your main collectables) are the fiddliest things to get in every level. They can range from mildly annoying, frustrating (the race), to downright impossible (waterloo world). That wouldn't be so bad if there was a way you could track down the ones you missed (you always miss one, guaranteed). But if you really want 101% you need to use the internet to track down the missing ones (itself a pain in the butt). I honestly had no problem with the Meat Circus first or second time. (The first time I did have problems with (one of) the final boss, but that was performance issues with my PC and me not configuring it properly). [Pro-tip: ignore everything in the first tent and just save the little kid and get to the top. You can come back later]One last thing I want to really highlight, is the settings of the levels. Every one of which is exploding with a creativity rarely seen in any videogame. My favorite is a toss-up between Waterloo World and The Milkman Conspiracy. (Though Lungfishoppolis comes in a close third)In the end, this is only my opinion, not everyone’s. I mean, what do you care, this game is how old now and every person on the internet has given their opinion on everything. But hear me out, even as old as it is, it is still one of the greatest video games of all time. Period. The humor, the charm, it's all there for all to see and play. The sequel is apparently coming out soon, I don't know what to think about that, but if it is half as good as the original the gaming world on the whole will be better for it. Signing off in the words of Coach Oleander that I think sum up the game quite nicely- "You shall engage the enemy in his own mentality! You shall chase his dreams! You shall fight his demons! You shall live his nightmares. And those of you who fight well, you will find yourselves on the path to becoming international secret agents — in other words... Psychonauts! The rest of you... will die!"

TL;DRBUY THIS GAME! If you have a controller, I'd recommend it over the keyboard and mouse as I've found it to be much easier to control Raz with a controller instead of the keyboard.Over a decade and the game still holds up.Psychonauts is truly a testament to great game design — released over a decade ago and still holds up well. The game features one of the most original stories this side of Spec Ops: The Line, and the humor is on-point though subtle. The characters are unique, and most importantly, human. Each one has their own problems, motivations and quirks. As the story progresses, you'll get to see characters' lives unfold, each one a different arc. I think the true achievement of Psychonaut's storytelling is that you, the protaganist, is never the main character of the story, but simply a conduit. Your actions move the story forward, but it's the lives of others that draw your attention and empathy.And my god, the level design. Instead of filling the game with gimmicky tricks that are used once (and never again, I'm looking at you Assassin's Creed, Bioshock, Dishonored, etc.), the levels in Psychonauts is designed in such a way that each ability will undoubtedly be used over and over again (except for Clairvoyence). The levels also do not feel repetitive. Even though the core mechanics never change from the first mission to the last, every mission has it's own little gimmick that makes that one particular level feel different than every other level.The soundtrack is on point, and even though the graphics undoubtedly feel a bit dated, when a game is this good, it doesn't really matter.

												The good -- A funny, original story with good voice acting and genuinely funny dialogue throughout. Can be childish at times, but it fits with the humor and juxtaposes well with some of the darker and more mature elements.- Great art direction, despite its age the graphics still don't look dated and fit with the look and feel of the game perfectly. The character design tends more towards cartoony characters whose appearance give you a good outline of their personality, and the environments vary widely from traditional platformer areas to mind bending levels that twist and turn through every axis.- Tight platformer mechanics, moving around and exploring the environments is easy and encouraged thanks to loads of hidden collectables. Its easy to keep track of your progress, and constantly unlocking something new, or being just about to, will keep you playing that one more level.The bad -- Occasional problems with the camera, the usual having to wrestle it under control from a preset position. Part and parcel of 3D platformers ported from consoles.- Some of the latter levels have some downright unfair sections with long runs between checkpoints and unforgiving level design that can become quite frustrating.- Optimization problems with Windows 7. There are loads of threads all over the net complaining of crashes and freeze-ups, which seem to only occur on Windows 7. True, running the game in compatibility mode (I used Windows 95) solves this issue but it seems like a glaring problem for a game on Steam, no matter how old.Personal Highlights (contains level spoilers, no storyline spoilers) -- Lungfishopolis - Destroying a city populated by fish as a giant Kaiju Theatre version of yourself. Complete with gameplay being interrupted by news flashes as the fish report on your rampage of destruction.- The Milkman Conspiracy - One of the most head bending levels I've seen in a platformer in recent times.- Razputin (the main character) is voiced brilliantly by Richard Horvitz (the voice of Invader Zim). YMMV on this one, but as a fan of the show I loved hearing the distinctive voice throughout.Summary -Won't be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like platformers and adventure games, Psychonauts is an excellent example of an original and unique take on the genre. It's fun to play, memorable in both its level design and its story, and, frankly, there's not much out there (especially recently) that compares to it. Let down by minor problems that plague many console to PC ports, but they don't hamper it enough to be a standout game.9/10Context - 9Challenge - 8Catharsis - 8

												I recommend this game tentatively. Pros: - Beautiful and Unique Art Style. It reminds me a bit of Invader Zim, but not so much so that I'd declare it a plain rip off. - Intricate and Masterful storytelling. The plot is interesting and keeps me coming back for more. I'm never just slogging through something hoping for a payoff. It's all a genuinely fun story.- Likable characters. Even the characters who barely get screen time or have no lines seem to be overflowing with personality. They feel very real, despite being so stylized. - Fun game mechanics. The psychic abilities are endlessly fun. Levitation is my absolute favorite, mainly because it frees up the movement of your character a lot, but there are several other abilities I really love. On top of being fun, they're necessary. Once a mechanic is introduced, they always give you a reason to use it. While you may eventually stop using it as often, it'll always come back a few more times.- Dialogue is witty and hilarious. It's not forced comedy like I see a lot of comedy games try to do. It's just funny, in a really natural way, and I found myself actually laughing out loud. Even jokes that fall flat were meant to do so, because the fact that the joke wasn't funny is part of the joke itself.- The vaults are probably my favorite part of the game. They're a sort of slide show deal, and there are usually two in every level. They're in depth explanations of certain points of that character's life, and they're a joy every time. - Bosses are challenging, but not impossible. They're all unique and just so fun. Cons: - The technology is from the PS2 era, and it shows. Some of the graphics are painfully outdated, and the pitful camera movement is a relic. You have to control the camera movement separately with your mouse, and it can tend to get frustrating during intense fights, trying to control the camera, move your character and target enemies. - Strange difficulty curve. The entire first section of the game is tutorials (understandably, considering the huge assortment of psychic abilities and mechanics they're trying to introduce) and at some point in the second half it suddenly jumps up to being extremely hard. I had to resort to a few lets plays at some parts because it was just so obtuse what you were supposed to be doing.- Figments and arrowheads were ridiculously annoying. Figments are somewhat transparent, so they tend to blend into the highly stylized backgrounds, making it almost impossible to know where they are at times. As for the arrowheads, they're practically everywhere, but at times the game demands you actively dig them up which just wasn't fun at all.- CRASHING. Good god, the crashing. At time of writing, the game has crashed at least 4 or 5 times today, which is why I'm writing this review now, hoping if I let it throw it's little tantrum for about half an hour it'll decide to work so I can continue playing. Perhaps it's just the computer I'm running it on (It's not really a gaming PC, but it is a high powered Mac) but it takes something away from the game when I'm saving every two steps in case the game decides to suddenly freeze and crash. Overall, I recommend it to anyone who wants to try something entirely new and different. It's a purely fun experience with a few technical issues that tend to drag it down at points. Despite the crashing and a few nit picky issues, I will continue playing it because I'm so invested, but if you don't think you could handle that, or don't have the patience for such a thing, I'd only recommend buying it on sale.

												Do you remember that feeling of mystery and adventure that hit you back in the days, when you took up a new game? I mean those almost new 3D adventure games with sharp shapes, a mind blowing story and infinite secrets. Oh my, how I miss those games. The were the first I played with on console and PC, and they still hold a special place in my memories. They had always original ideas, not like some everlasting sequence of sequels of today; and nobody explained to you anything (except for a basic commands tutorial), you had to figure out everything by yourself, with curiosity and intelligence, and this made the winning so satisfying. And why am I acting like an old nostalgic gamer? Because Psychonauts is such a game, and I waited way too much to play it. It showed me how much games have changed over the years, for the best and for the worst, and how much we can learn from the masterpieces of the past to craft majestic titles in our future.Now, at the end of this (first) adventure in the Psyconauts Summer Camp, I am sincerely moved, by a game that reminded me why I started to play videogames when I was a boy, and why I still play them as a man.Vi ricordate  quella sensazione di mistero e aventura che vi prendeva quando iniziavate un nuovo gioco anni fa? Mi riferisco a quei giochi di avventura in 3D, ai tempi praticamente nuovi,  con le forme aguzze, una storia incredibile e segreti infiniti. Dio, quanto mi mancano quei giochi. Sono stati i primi a cui ho giocato su console e su pc, e occupano ancora oggi un posto speciale nei miei ricordi. Avevano sempre idee originali, non come certe infinite serie di sequel di oggi; e nessuno ti spiegava nulla (se non per un tutorial sui comandi base), dovevi capire tutto da solo, con curiosità e intelligenza, e questo rendeva la vittoria molto più soddisfacente.E perché mi sto comportando come un nostalgico vecchio gamer? Perchè Psychonauts è un gioco come quelli, e ho aspettato decisamente troppo per  giocarci. Mi ha mostrato quanto i videogiochi siano cambiati in questi anni, per in meglio e in peggio, e quanto possiamo imparare dai capolavori del passato per creare titoli meravigliosi in futuro.Ora, alla fine di questa (prima) avventura al Campo Estivo per Psychonauts, sono sinceramente commosso, da un gioco che mi ha ricordato perché ho iniziato a giocare ai videogiochi da bambino, e perché ci gioco ancora da adulto.

												Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.Psychonauts is a quirky, offbeat game set in a special summer camp for clairvoyant kids, in which a group of psychic children end up in a wacky adventure filled with brain-stealing hijinks, psychic secret agents, and a little romance on top of everything else. It's rooted in the sorts of 3D platforming sensibilities we've all come to know over the years. But there's a SPIN to the game--its psychic theme--which adds some cool puzzle-solving to the usual platform-jumping and swinging associated with the genre. Psychonauts also bears the unmistakable mark of designer Tim Schafer (known for classic adventure games Grim Fandango, Full Throttle, and Day of the Tentacle), thanks to a hilarious array of peculiar characters and a story that never fails to entertain. Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.It took four years and two publishers, but Psychonauts is finally here, and no worse for the wear, it seems.The heart and soul of Psychonauts is Razputin--or, Raz, for short--a big-headed, goggle-sporting psychic prodigy who sneaks his way into a mysterious summer camp that happens to be a training ground for the titular psychonauts, a group of psychic secret agents. Raz, it seems, has run away from his home in the circus and wants to become a psychonaut himself. Grudgingly, the counselors of the camp accept Raz into the group (albeit only for a day, until his father can come get him and take him home). However, it doesn't take long for strange things to start happening around camp. Raz, as well as other children, find that they're suffering from similar nightmares. Strange psychic interference seems to be POPPING UP all over the place, and not long after that, the brains of the other campers start disappearing, leaving the campers as soulless, TV-obsessed husks. As the hero of the story, Raz is on a mission to solve these various mysteries and uncover the crazy conspiracy behind it all.The basic plot itself reads like typical platformer fodder, but there's a lot more to Psychonauts' story than can be summed up in a single paragraph. This is largely due to the game's bizarre cast of characters, of which there are many. Raz himself is a highly likable hero; he's cute, heroic, funny, and also a little awkward at times. He fits the bill of the overenthusiastic yet not-quite-ready hero to the letter and it's hard not to feel sympathetic to his plight. But beyond Raz, there's a great supporting cast, with roughly two dozen other characters who play parts both large and small in the story. The counselors consist of Coach Oleander, an overly aggressive drill sergeant; Milla Vodello, a somewhat ditzy and party-happy go-go girl; Agent Nein, a pale-skinned, sweater-sporting scientist of indeterminate Eastern European origin; and Ford Cruller, a mysterious old man who seems to exist in about eight different places at once. These counselors join the crazy array of campers, as well as other strange people and creatures you'll encounter, to drive the storyline, and thanks to the game's excellent design, you'll have no shortage of opportunities to get ATTACHED to them.Initially, Psychonauts feels like a very open-ended game, especially because upon your first venture into the camp area, you'll find yourself able to just wander around, chatting it up with other campers or even just listening in on their completely INSANE conversations. The camp and its many areas make up a hub world, where you can access lots of different things, including a camp store, where you can buy helpful items, an underground tram that cuts down on backtracking, and all sorts of little hidden areas that yield bonus items. However, the biggest boon for the camp world is all the little bouts of dialogue you can discover. Depending on what stage of the game you're at, the conversations change up quite a bit, meaning you're not often going to hear a lot of repeats. This is great, especially because there's just so much of the dialogue. In some instances, you can literally just stand next to a pair of characters while they converse for about five minutes or longer and never hear the same line twice. And it's almost always really funny stuff.However, the most interesting aspects of Psychonauts' characters don't come from their real-world conversations, but rather from their internal monologue. As Psychonauts revolves around a bunch of psychics, the bulk of your time will be spent traversing the perils of people's minds. This is where Psychonauts truly shines. You'll be able to enter the minds of more than a dozen different characters in the game, and each mind serves as one of its main levels. Each level is completely unique. For instance, when you enter the head of Coach Oleander, you'll find a war-torn landscape filled with constant explosions, plants made out of ammunition, and, for reasons not immediately apparent, lots and lots of meat. In another example, you enter the mind of a crazed security guard named Boyd Cooper, who is utterly obsessed with nonsensical conspiracies and someone called "The Milkman." His mental landscape looks like a 1950s-era suburban neighborhood that's been picked up by a pair of hands, twisted into a topsy-turvy fun house, and occupied exclusively by shadowy agents in TRENCH COATS who try to convince you that they're just simple street workers, or hedge trimmers, or grieving widows, despite their obviously ulterior motives. It's all totally weird, but also undeniably unique.No two minds are exactly alike in Psychonauts, both aesthetically and in terms of gameplay. Granted, you will be spending at least some of YOUR time in each level engaging in the usual platforming shenanigans, like jumping and double-jumping over platforms, swinging from poles, walking tightropes, and so on. When the game is in full-on platformer mode, it plays very well. The controls are tight, the camera is rarely ever a problem, and it's generally pretty easy to get Raz around without screwing up, at least on the Xbox. The PC version controls well enough too, provided of course you have a good USB controller, as the keyboard and mouse controls just don't feel right for this type of game (and even with a USB controller, camera control can be a bit of a pain). If there's any one criticism to be mounted here across both platforms, it's that the game is rarely ever that difficult, save for a few specific parts that are actually quite tough. You can't call the game a total breeze, either, but most experienced players shouldn't have any problems mastering the basic play mechanics pretty quickly.The inside of a person's mind can be a pretty crazy place.Even though the game isn't particularly hard, at least it's not repetitive. The goals and challenges of each level are totally exclusive. In one level, you'll find yourself playing a bizarre board game against a mental projection of Napoleon Bonaparte. You'll shrink down to "fun size" to recruit new pieces to YOUR cause, and then you'll return to your normal size so that you can move them around. In another level, you're fighting neon-tinted luchadores and a big, hulking bull in what looks like a velvet painting of a congested Spanish city. It's with this kind of variety that Psychonauts manages to achieve its high level of quality.It also helps that the game has more to it than just a lot of jumping around. There are puzzles to be solved in Psychonauts, as well as battles to be fought, and both require use of Raz's list of crazy psychic powers. You start out only with a basic melee attack at your disposal, but as you play and collect items scattered about both the real world and mental worlds, you'll be able to upgrade Raz's rank and earn new powers, like telekinesis. 84/100

												TL;DR: A great story with good gameplay. I recommend you play it, but SPECIFICALLY on Windows, with an Xbox 360 Controller, and with the Psychopad mod.Psychonauts was the first game that I ever bought (with money) on my Steam account. After hearing good reviews (such as the one from Yahtzee on Zero Punctuation), I had decided to pick it up. In the end, I'd consider it one of my favorite games of all time.The core gameplay actually feels a lot like a 3D Mario game. It's a 3rd Person 3D Platformer with some fairly intricate platforming. This difficulty is a little on the tough side, but it never really feels vicious other than the last level of the game. The game gives you a double jump from the beginning of the game, which makes the platforming a bit easier, and about a third of the way through the game, it gives you an ability that allows you to fall slower, which makes some of the later-game platforming more bearable. Your main attack is a punch that has a fairly large range. You also gain abilities as you progress though the game that allow you to attack from more of a distance. For these abilities, the game gives you a lock-on system that is very similar to Zelda's Z-Targeting. This usually works well, but can get frustrating at times when there are a lot of enemies on the screen at once.The level design in this game is excellent. The story behind the levels is that you are entering the minds of different characters, so each level is designed to represent that character's psyche. Because all of the characters you enter the minds of are well characterized, each level is itself a strong representation of the characters. The most interesting levels are correlated to the most interesting characters, with Boyd's level being particularly famous. There are hidden memory vaults, along with scripted events and cutscenes in the levels that help to further characterize the people who's minds you enter, helping to create a better overall connection between the levels you play in and the story that moves the game along.The story in the game is fantastic. You play a psychic boy named Raz who runs away from home (which happens to be a circus), to sneak into a summer camp that trains psychic kids to try to make them "psychic secret agents" called psychonauts. He discovers a conspiracy that threatens the entire camp, and it's up to Raz to save the camp. All the characters that you meet in the game are all well characterized, and makes the story much more interesting. The game has a lot of humor in it, and Double Fine has done a good job of making sure the jokes actually work. Psychonauts is one of the funniest games I've ever played.One aspect of the game that I didn't really like was the leveling system. There are a number of collectables scattered throughout the game (both in the levels and the overworked) that increase your level, and leveling up gives you a few required abilities (for the first few level tiers), then upgrades your existing abilities. Some of these upgrades actually makes the game a LOT easier, meaning that if you don't go out of your way to find these collectables, the game can be much more difficult. However, replaying the game to get 100% of the collectables is a lot of fun. Once you complete the story once, it's a lot of fun to restart the game and aim to get 100% of the collectables and achievements.This game can be downloaded for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux, but the later two ports are actually pretty broken. I played the Mac version first, and I experienced serious performance issues, multiple graphics issues, and crashes. From what I've heard, the linux version doesn't fair much better than the Mac version. While the Windows version isn't perfect, it is certainly better than the other two. You can try to get it to run under Wine, but I can't make any promises about how well that will work.The keyboard+mouse controls for this game really suck. The game was designed around a controller, so you should play it with one. I recommend the 360 controller because the game has controller mapping and vibration support for it. If you have a wireless 360 controller already, just get a cheap Chinese knock-off of the wireless receiver (I can find them for around $10 USD) and force Windows to use the official drivers for it in the Device Manager. The game won't have the button prompts for the controller unless you use the Psychopad mod to add them. Be sure to turn off Steam Cloud Sync before running the patcher though, or the controls may be remapped in such a way to prevent the button prompts from appearing.In the end, I'd recommend this game. I consider this game to be one of my favorite games of all time, and for good reason. It's gameplay is fun, it's story is amazing, and I will always enjoy going back and replaying the game. If you haven't played this game, then you should play it.

												Exploring the minds of other campers was so entertaining that I feel it made this game worth it in spite of the near constant crashing issues that seem to plague a segment of the playerbase and the other negatives I'll get to.Pros:-Each level feels distitinct from the others and no one level is "that level" that I hated to play-Story pacing is adequate, I felt introduced to new plot points often enough to remain interested-The characters are fleshed out enough that the player can dig into their pasts and motivations through dialog or power  interactions (claravoiyance lets you see how they view you, for example)-The story was coherent and had a satsifiying conclusion and the main characters exhibited growth as charactersCons:-The player is rewarded with additional powers or upgrades by collecting a large number of collectables but the upgrades feel largely useless and the entire game could be beaten easily while ignoring the collectables-The Confusion grenade power was shoehorned in for one mini-boss and one boss fight in the same level and then has no effect on any enemies following that point.-There is a story-related point where the player recieves the Levitation power but subsequent levels are not designed around its use and it utterly removes all platforming from the game.-Constant crashing. This is only alleviated by the game autosaving at every loading screen so the player loses no progress.-The arrowhead currency is mostly useless except the two times the player is forced to hunt for them to buy an item in order to progress with the game. One of these two items is a dousing rod that only helps find more arrowheads to save up for the more expensive plot-related item.Again, even with the near-useless upgrades and powers, the forced hunting of arrowheads, and constant crashing Psychonauts is worth a play. The characters are interesting, the story is satsifying and not even a slightly lackluster platforming experience can detract from that.

The puzzles, whilst being original and challenging, can also present a certain sense of frustration at the sometimes sheer amount of abstract thinking one is required to do. VERDICT:Buy Immediately (9.8/10)Completion Time: 25-30 hoursBottom Line: "Don't just play this game for the memorable story, the characters, or the adventure, JUST DO IT FOR THE KIDS MAN."PROS+Awesome story+Suprisingly mature humor+Winning gameplay formula+Hilarious characters+Unique worldCONS-You will sometimes get lost-Platforming difficultiesREVIEWThis is an adult's game disguised in XS kids clothing. On the outside, this is a game about a children's day camp, but venture a little deeper and you'll find one of the most quarky, hilarious, and enthralling adventures that successfully stands the test of time.Our hero is Rasputin (AKA Raz), a young boy that runs away from his job at the circus in order to hone his supernatural abilities at a day camp for young psychics. It only takes a day for him to realize that something is terribly wrong: some of the campers are starting to literally lose their minds. It is your job to not only become an official psychic expert, but to find the culprit behind the missing brains!This is your traditional adventure-platformer in the same vain as Mario 64 or the Spyro franchise. You'll be running around completing tasks for different camp patrons to advance the story, all while traversing terrain and taking down baddies.Let me just say that this cast of characters is one of the most endearingly dysfunctional groups of people you'll ever meet. From delusional old men to stereotypical FBI agents to a bully with a lisp, all the classic stereotypes are in full force here.Gameplay is split into two different zones: free roam and brain sequences. During free roam you can roam the camp grounds searching for collectables and meeting new people. Brain sequences take place inside your brain and involve whimsical levels reminiscent of a bad dream, or someone that's tripping really hard. Everything in this game, regardless of location, has the same distinct art style, and this is the type of style that doesn't age with time.The gameplay itself is incredibly fun. Throughout the game you'll be gaining new abilities to take on your foes. These include telekenesis, levetation, invisibility, and more. Each ability has its purpose, and will come into play at some point in the game. There are also many puzzle aspects of gameplay, and these puzzles are damn fun. My favorite puzzle was when I had to play a game of Catan (not actually Catan but something similar) in order to defeat a boss. It was one of the coolest levels I have ever played.The cons are few and in between. Sometimes I got lost in this game, and it was unclear where I needed to go to advance the story. Also, some platforming sections were frustrating, or it wasn't necessarily obvious what I had to do to advance in the level. Regardless of these hiccups, I always managed to find my way eventually.If there's one thing I want you to take away from this review its this: this game is memorable. Each level is incredibly unique. Each character is different and has their own idiosycracies that make them hilarious. Each boss fight has different mechanics that make you think. And the last level is a tremendous challenge that makes you feel like you've accomplished something monumental upon its completion.Don't just play this game for the memorable story, the characters, or the adventure, JUST DO IT FOR THE KIDS MAN.

Inside Someone's MindStory:You take the Role of Raz, who just escaped the life of a circus performer to join a summer camp for children with Psychic abilities, with an unreasonable goal of becoming a Psychonaut in just mere days.Fortunately for Raz or perhaps not. This once peaceful learning camp is now in danger, as kids seem to be turning into TV obsessed Zombies.Its now up to him with the help of his teachers to uncover the culprit.The concept of going inside someone's mind,is what makes this game so appealing to me.You jump between the real world/hub world, a safe and familiar place, to this fantastic sets, showing the mind's representation of each characters fears.Its a great idea, with endless possibilities and Double Fine did good use of it. Every character as their own very distinct personalities and painful memories, each have their own unique mental world.As to what you should expect from the story in this gamePsychonauts started as a turned down idea for Full Throttle, and was the first title for Tim Schafer´s own company, Double Fine.This is what most people used to remember Shafer for, it's a Multi-layered narrative with alot of his own humor and charmGraphics:Psychonauts was never a good looking game, but the strong art style makes up for it in a way.If you ever watched animation around the 90´s, you probably noticed what Psychonauts is going for. All of these characters are human but with desproporcional bodies, sometimes hard to even recognize them as such.That art style extends to the sets themselves and everything fits perfectly togetherGameplay:Not cluttered but a bit all overFrom old school platformers to collectathons, Speed sections on rails and puzzle elements, bosses, fetch-questsyou name it.I will say it, i loved this game, but its hardly a fully fledged platformer, in the later levels it even gets a bit frustrating, calculating and timing your jump, is not always easy, thanks to flawed gameplay mechanicsTLTR?Pros:+Story+art style +Original concept+Variety+Strong characters+Voice acting+Humor+Music (sounds like Danny Elfman)Cons:-Textures-Platforming mechanics -Randomly crashes (not often, +with autosaves it's unlikely to lose progress)Score: 4/5

												Psychonauts is one of the best games I've ever played. It's a third person action/adventure game with a great story about brain theft at a psychic summer camp, and you're thrown into the middle of it as a psychic who ran away from the circus.Being set in a psychic summer camp, you already know you're in for some great special abilities like telekinesis and levitation, but by far the best feature of Psychonauts is that levels are created by entering someone's mind and dealing with all their emotional problems, fighting off the creatures that lurk within, and sorting out their emotional baggage (quite literally). Once you complete a stage, you leave that person in a much better emotional and mental state... well... that's the idea anyway.The musical score, sound effects, and particularly the voice acting is top tier, with the main character, Raz, voiced by Richard Steven Horvitz - who is probably best known as the voice of Invader Zim or maybe as Daggett from Angry Beavers.As good as Psychonauts is, it does have a few issues. The camera angle can be a bit annoying at times, but it's mostly alright. Also, I found myself unable to beat the game using a keyboard and mouse setup - one of the later levels has some platforming that felt impossible, but after I got myself an Xbox 360 controller I was able to get past that tricky section, so I'd say a decent controller is an absolute must.10 out of 10 I don't care if it had a few minor issues, the rest was so good I couldn't possibly give it a lower score.

												As a fan of 3D platformers with a spare dollar to spend during a Steam sale, I decided to give Double Fine Productions' cult classic Psychonauts a try. After hearing about the alleged creativity and uniqueness the game offered, I wondered if the reviews were to be believed.  Psychonauts follows the adventure of an eager young psychic named Razputin as he uncovers the secrets behind Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp, along with the minds of various characters around the area. When things take a turn for the worst, it becomes up to him to put an end to it and save his fellow campers. Though the distinct graphical style may initially scare some players off, its fits the tone of the game to a 'T'. Psychonauts seems to take much of its inspiration from Western animation in terms of its character tropes and setting, and it definitely works. Combined with the superb voice acting, interesting plot and remarkable concept, the atmosphere is definitely an enjoyable one. Along with the characters and overall mood the game gives off, the level design and gameplay is superb. The hub area is a nice concept, allowing the player to see what their favorite campers are up to while they take a break from the story. Along with housing numerous secret items, it also allows them to quickly transmit to and fro each section at will. Being a game called "Psychonauts", it certainly shines during the levels taking place in the minds Razputin enters. Each of these possesses a unique feeling and theme to reflect the personality of the character in question. Each level also hosts their own set of challenges, and will make the player eager to progress and see what awaits them. Unfortunately, there is not much left to be explored of each world once it is cleared for the first time – the player only needs to return unless they are aiming to gather all the collectable items.On an entirely different note, the player is given an item early in the game that allows them to ask for advice if they are stuck. The advice offered is simple, yet effective and allows the player to work around most obstacles without the game flat-out doing it for them. The game does not push or force the player to use this feature, allowing this to appeal to both those who are easily frustrated and those who want to work things out for themselves.Of course no game is perfect, and Psychonauts is no exception to this rule. While I do not intend to sound like a certain critic featured within the game, Psychonauts possesses a few flaws which prevent it from becoming my absolute favorite. The keyboard controls feel very confusing and complicated, making a controller almost necessary to play this game; although once this is done it handles rather nicely. A certain level in the game titled "The Milkman Conspiracy" prevents you from progressing unless you purchase an expensive item which removes the object blocking the path, which have previously only appeared in locations that would indicate this would be an optional side quest. Though the game warns the player of this obstacle beforehand, this still forces them to tediously grind for currency. The very same level also possesses a more puzzle-based structure which requires a copious amount of backtracking as well as repeatedly searching the area for objects which can easily be missed. A miniboss is also fought here twice with no warning, variation, or possibility of skipping. While this is an understandable attempt to give the level some of the action offered by previous worlds, it becomes tedious and annoying when introduced in this fashion. Thankfully, this area is one of the game's most humor-rich areas which makes up for a good deal of its flaws, but it still is far from ideal. Though the game has its imperfections here and there, Psychonauts is certainly an enjoyable and memorable experience for fans of the platformer genre. On a final note - if you do purchase the game, be wary that much of the game's content is spoiled through achievements and trading cards.

												TL;DR: Buy it.Just like most of the people who have written reviews about this game, I bought and played it during the winter sale of 2016. I had heard positive remarks about this game in the past, and it was only $0.99, so I decided to play it. Psychonauts is very different from the norm of video games. It has a nice art style. All of the characters, ranging from the most unimportant campers, to the camp counselors, all have a personality. The game plays nicely, although the platforming is a bit unfair at times. The fighting's okay. It's not really anything groundbreaking. The thing that really sets this game apart is the concept of a summer camp for psychics. You can learn different abilities via badges, the way you access different worlds is by putting a tiny little door on someone's head, and beat up men wearing suits with giant stamps. It's also funny. I found this game to be actually funny. It has clever writing, a nice art style, a fresh, new concept, and overall, it's just a great game. I will have to say that one of its biggest issues is the difficulty curve. At the end of the game, there was this one segment that I could not get past. It took me half an hour to get past that one stage. The game's not very difficult at first, aside from the psychic bears roaming the camp, but at the end, ♥♥♥♥ went balls to the walls. It also doesn't have a good replayability. Once you finish the game, there's not a lot you can do. You could try looking for all of the scavenger items, but that's about it. I definately recommend this game to anyone who wants a fresh, new concept and funny writing.

												Psychonauts is a game that stands on its setting. First off, the environment is wonderfully designed. The setting is a summer camp for psychics, and the everyday beauty of nature is distorted by the childlike playfulness ofthe supernatural elements. Boardwalks don't just wind down forest paths, but undulate through space, twisting and turning like something out of a Tim Burton film. The characters are engaging and bizarre, their quirks lovingly detailed, both in appearance and characterization, making everyone unique. There are no generic "background characters" in this game; every character has a backstory, a personality, and their own plot that winds through the narrative of the game. Once you get into the mechanics, however, there are some problems. There are some control issues, and most of the challenge comes, not from the game, but trying to marshal the controls into doing what you want, rather than actually using them to accomplish goals. The only other blemish on the face of this otherwise wonderful game is that the leveling is a bit grind-y, and centered around a series of scavenger hunts, rather than actual gameplay. That said, I feel that a traditional "Combat->XP" system would not have worked with this game, as combat seems to be something that happens when it has to, rather than a constant method of progressing through the game.In short, the play is a little slow and glitchy, but with the engaging setting, you won't mind it much.

												Psychonauts is a game that stands on its setting. First off, the environment is wonderfully designed. The setting is a summer camp for psychics, and the everyday beauty of nature is distorted by the childlike playfulness ofthe supernatural elements. Boardwalks don't just wind down forest paths, but undulate through space, twisting and turning like something out of a Tim Burton film. The characters are engaging and bizarre, their quirks lovingly detailed, both in appearance and characterization, making everyone unique. There are no generic "background characters" in this game; every character has a backstory, a personality, and their own plot that winds through the narrative of the game. Once you get into the mechanics, however, there are some problems. There are some control issues, and most of the challenge comes, not from the game, but trying to marshal the controls into doing what you want, rather than actually using them to accomplish goals. The only other blemish on the face of this otherwise wonderful game is that the leveling is a bit grind-y, and centered around a series of scavenger hunts, rather than actual gameplay. That said, I feel that a traditional "Combat->XP" system would not have worked with this game, as combat seems to be something that happens when it has to, rather than a constant method of progressing through the game.In short, the play is a little slow and glitchy, but with the engaging setting, you won't mind it much.

												This was...a truly wondeful game. Initially, I first came across Physconauts as a picture, one of those random pictures that sometimes appear on google images for some reason or another, intrigued by the oddball style of character design, I looked further into the game, and I was struck by it's capacity to keep you interested. The music for all stages reflected well not only upon the mind of who you were exploring, with each person's mind receiving a unique piece. The character designs are not based on traditional aesthetic values, but still create a diverse cast who, while a great many of them are barely mentioned in the actual plot, are prominent in the many little side affairs that make up camp life (which I found created a realisticness in a place where not too many would expect it). One of the main things I really liked about the game was the exploration factor, in that, the Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp proved a vast place to poke, jump, burn, and run around, in fact, a moderate chunk of late game fighting capacity relies on your exploration. Interestingly enough, Psychonauts doesn't rely on overt violence to keep you entertained, although there usually is mental censors of some kind to fight through as minor obstacles in most minds. Instead, you must explore through various places, figuring out how to best get around (One case being how to go up a street without being run over by a bull.) That isn't to say the boss fights aren't challenging. Far from it, as the boss fights I've encountered here, rely not on overt violence, but rather figuring out how to use various psychic powers to exploit the enemy's weakness and win from there. Combine this with amusing dialogue, jokes for all ages, and minor plot arcs which lead one to speculation about real life people based on fictional characters, and many other things which make the Game of Psychonauts a Must Play.
