												I realize that this review is coming a little late and it's highly likely that no one will ever read this, but I only recently started writing my own game reviews and I would be highly remiss if I didn't put in a plug for my all-time favotite game.The graphics are showing their age, but other than that I can't think of any aspect of Psychonauts that I wouldn't descrive as excellent even today, almost ten years after the game's original release.  The gameplay, pacing, music, voice acting and story are all top-notch; but above and beyond all that, it has one feature that's utterly unequaled in any other game I've ever played: style!  What's more, due to the game's variety it reaches this incredibly high standard several times over.As a psychonaut, your job is to psychically enter the minds of others to achieve your goals.  Thus, each level is custom-tailored to the mind of the individual you're exploring.  In your instructor Mina's mind, you race through a dance party on a thought-bubble; in the mind of a giant mutated fish, you're a Godzilla-like monster laying waste to a city; and in the mind of a paranoid conspiracy nut, you make your way through a twisted suburban landscape where every bush conceals a hidden camera.  The masterpiece, though, has to be the "Black Velvetopia" level, which is a black velvet painting come to life.  Words don't do it justice -- It has to be experienced to be truly appreciated.The art, music, tone and even your goals are completely different in each mind you enter.  Any one of these levels could be considered a superior game all on its own; but together they constitute one of the greatest games ever made.The only bad news is that it looks like the game's developer was a one-hit wonder -- Double Fine hasn't since produced a single noteworthy title.

Intro & SummaryPsychonauts is a fun journey and romp as a kid at a psychic summer camp, learning psychic powers and using them to explore a fun story, and equally fantastically designed world.Clocking in at 13 hours, but has such a surprisingly rich and detailed main story that you'll likely clock in at least double that.HighlightsThe core of a good single player is it's storyline or arc. I routinely come back and run through this game every couple years, and find new things I completely missed the last time.MistakesHonestly, practically none. You could argue that one of the few thousand set pieces are flawed slightly to make a challenging section frustrating, or go wrong once or twice, but even that is a stretch on what is pretty much a perfectly designed and polished game, which somehow still feels quirky and personal.BuyingPsychonauts is routinely available for $5 or less, and has even hit as low as $1 on Steam and Indie Bundles. 												This game is probably the most frustrating yet still lovable game I've played in the last few years. I'm sure if I had played the game when it came out the clunky platforming wouldn't have been as frustrating (okay yea it would be but at least I would be used to it) but it still didn't hinder the gameplay all that much (except when it bugged out during a boss). It reminded me of the platformers from when I was a kid and had charming humor you just don't see anymore. Raz is a spunky little kid who is joined by a colorful (and colorful MOUTHED) class of superpowered children who need a better adult than they got at camp.The story is wonderfully told through the "minds" of some eccentric people and through the eyes of a naive and hopeful child. It's sure to throw you for a loop and back again. The art style is off putting at first because of the weird and just purposely ugly designs but they grow on you. The levels are just beautiful (especially Black Velvetopia) and I've never seen anything like them before. They make your head spin and frustrate you, but it's all a part of the fun.The only bad parts of this game I think are the clunky outdated controls making it hard to platform, missable achievements, the final level Meat Circus... even the achievement says "i thought that was unbeatable" and for a slow computer it is!, and let's not forget the monotonous collecting of all figments.But it does have replay value if you miss some things, you just won't want to 100% it again. It's unforgettable dialogue and one of a kind cast really leave a lasting impression on you. I'm glad I got to play it first as an adult because I wouldn't have gotten half the jokes 10 years ago. I think it would do well to have a remake (or at least remaster with better controls) because I already miss this game. I'll be playing again some day.

												Its a game by Tim Schafer game. If that doesn't sell you, then I guess I'll have to talk about the game.Psychonauts is a platformer that has collectathon elements, powers, and a ranking system, as well as a large hub world. The main chunk of the game and gameplay takes place inside the minds of individuals around the psychics' camp,calling Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp.The characters are the best part of this game. This game is amazing in every aspect, but the characters are easily the best part of it. They're quirky, they have their own permanent personalities, they have backstories told through slideshows within that person's level, they are full of life and are portrayed so well by their respective voice actors that you never get the sense that they're people in a room recording lines of dialogue, you get immersed into the world of the psychonauts and the characters slowly have their affect on you. They also teach you valuable life lessons (for instance, control over emotions and saying that you cannot lock it completely away, or you'll explode inside Sasha Nein's marksman training). Honestly, the rest of the game works as well as any other decent 3D paltformer/collectathon, and I can't help but comparing it to Conker's Bad Fur Day, but with fewer curse words. It functions well and would otherwise not stand out, but because of its writing and its characters (and in Psychonaut's case, its art style too. CBFD looked a lot like Banjo & Kazooie). Its powers are neat and the premise is certaintly unique, but the characters really bring this game to life.Double Fine Productions are similar to Vigil games, as many of their games are huge cult classics, that weren't huge at their release, but have over time garnered a huge following. I just hope Double Fine doesn't go the way of Vigil.Overall, I highly recommend it to any 3D platforming fan. Its quirky, it pokes fun and its overall a blast to play. 10/10 from me, Double Fine. I cannot wait for Psychonauts 2 to come out in...2018, supposedly...I just hope its worth the wait and meets expectations
